awd_titl_txt: EAGER:  Collaborative:  A Criminology-Based Simulation of Dynamic Adversarial Behavior in Cyberattacks
awd_abstract_narration:
In 2016, the cyberthreat landscape showcased advanced attack techniques, escalated attack frequency, and high levels of adversarial sophistication. Conventional cyberattack management is response-driven, with organizations focusing their efforts on detecting threats, rather than anticipating adversarial actions. This reactive approach has limited efficacy, as it does not capture advanced and sophisticated adversaries, mutating or unknown malware, living-off-the-land techniques or new variants being deployed. There is thus an immediate need for a paradigm shift in the area of cybersecurity. Security experts are calling for anticipatory or proactive defense measures that focus on adversarial behavior and movement. This research aims to develop a criminological theory that captures the dynamics of cybercrime and a corresponding simulator to generate attack scenarios that adapts to ever changing and diverse cyber vulnerabilities, defense, and adversary tactics. 

This research has two connected objectives: (1) Develop (and evaluate) an integrated Dynamic Routine Activities Theory (DRAT), which examines the continually changing interaction between offender, target, and guardian (OTG) along cyberattack trajectories aided by Monte-Carlo simulation; and (2) Understand how variations in OTG impact dynamic adversarial attack trajectories. Specifically, how can these variations and amounts of variations be measured, modeled and simulated, and what might these variations imply for DRAT -- Understanding adversarial attack trajectories, and how these can be disrupted to impact adversaries, will be instrumental in comprehending anticipatory cyber defense and ultimately contribute to the paradigm shift towards proactive cybersecurity.  This exploratory, multidisciplinary research marries the two disciplines of criminology and computer engineering to push the research frontier on proactive cybersecurity. This groundbreaking intersection will generate new criminological theoretical knowledge, mixed-method innovations, and theoretically-informed simulation that prepare defenders with preemptive and comprehensive knowledge and tools in facing adaptive and sophisticated adversaries.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: TEMPLE UNIVERSITY-OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Temple University - Of The Commonwealth System of Higher Educati

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative project explored cyberadversarial behavior through interdisciplinary analysis of both in-person observations and intrusion logs collected through cybersecurity exercises. The intellectual merit and broader impact of the Temple team's work over the three-year project period includes:

1. Taxonomy of factors influencing adversarial decision-making

Teams with diverse skill sets served as a major advantage and resulted in an increased likelihood of successful cyberattacks. Adversarial groups with strong team bonds and prior experience working together were more likely to succeed. Members would support each other, work on different tasks, and respond more effectively to roadblocks. Defender disruption and self-made errors could set adversaries back; but adapting quickly ensured that they achieved their objectives effectively. Stress and fatigue often resulted in incorrect or poor decision-making, which impacted attack efficiency. Adversaries experienced major boosts in morale when they accomplished a key milestone, made a major finding, or overcame a roadblock. Adversaries also experienced moments of discouragement when things did not go according to plan. These discouraging moments could be brought about by errors, limited skill sets, and poor planning, which made it harder for adversaries to make good decisions that would increase the success of their attacks. Thus, a combination of technical prowess, group dynamics, and behavioral traits collectively shaped adversarial decision-making and the ultimate effectiveness of cyberattacks.

2. Metrics for gauging adversarial performance

The interdisciplinary nature of this project shed light on both typical technical and social aspects to assess adversarial performance. The technical metrics included:

(i) methods: an adversary's toolbox consists of different specializations, such as network, host, application, and social engineering.

(ii) information-gathering: this is often the first and critical step in performing cyberattacks, because the tester must understand all the different input vectors in an application that can be attacked. Passive reconnaissance refers to gathering information without accessing the network. Active reconnaissance refers to connecting to the network to examine preliminary responses from the target.

(iii) attack generation: cyberadversaries iterate through each vulnerability and develop attacks which are attempted against the target’s system and are necessary for its exploitation.

(iv) quantity of findings: determining the quantity of vulnerabilities found refers not only to the sheer number of identified security concerns left susceptible to potential cybercriminals but also to the number of unique components of those identified vulnerabilities that can be leveraged in cyberattacks.

(v) quality of findings: in addition to the quantity of vulnerabilities found, the quality of those vulnerabilities was equally important. For instance, cyberadversaries may find just a few vulnerabilities, yet those few vulnerabilities could lead to more harmful security breaches or theft of information when exploited.

The social metrics included team skills and bonding of group members (see section 1), and also preparation and communication. Adversaries could practice their skillsets in simulated environments to test their technical prowess, practice team communication and decision-making, and time-management and project management skills.

3. Interdisciplinary methodology

The interdisciplinary nature of this project helped develop holistic codebooks and data collection methods that merged both technical and social sciences.

(i) An attack technique codebook was developed collaboratively with the social science and technical research teams to define various techniques that could be used in cyberattacks. This ensured consistency across corresponding data collection methods of observations and technical logs.

(ii) A criminological codebook was developed to map offender, target, and guardian interactions that would allow for effective data collection. For instance, offender-specific variables included time, effort, skills, knowledge, emotions, research, alliance, and intent. Target-specific variables included architecture and vulnerabilities. Guardian-specific variables included response time, prevention, intrusion detection, deception, and disruption.

(iii) A multidisciplinary methodology was developed combining social science observational methods and technical log data. First, the social science researchers directly observed the actions of team engaging in CPTC. Second, the technical researchers deployed Suricata intrusion detection sensors to record the technical observables of the teams’ intrusion activities. This complementary approach shows great potential that was not viable via only the individual analysis. For example, the integrated analysis revealed previously invisible collaborations between team members. Another example of the interdisciplinary findings is that the time spent for different attack stages are significantly different from what the volume of intrusion alerts indicates. This is not unexpected because actions such as port scans take little time to prepare but generate a large amount of intrusion alerts, while a specific exploit takes time to prepare and generates very few intrusion alerts (or no alerts in some cases). Another finding from this multidisciplinary analysis is that adversarial attack chains are not sequential or linear, but rather cyclical and repetitive.

This interdisciplinary collaborative project broadened our understanding of adversarial behavior, attack chain models, and how to integrate social and technical sciences. This understanding shed light on the relevance for interdisciplinary research and dialog to go beyond the limitations of individual disciplines and gain a holistic perspective on cybersecurity.


Last Modified: 12/22/2021
Modified by: Aunshul Rege
